text:
[This is My Architecture] 
[Voodoo:]
[Performance Recommendations Using Machine Learning]

Hello and welcome
to This is My Architecture.
Today I'm pleased to welcome Voodoo.

[Robin Mizreh] [Technical Lead, Big Data Expert Voodoo] 
[Patrick Madec] [Partner Solutions Architect AWS]
- Hello Robin.
- Hello.
So, you're a Tech Lead at Voodoo,
can you tell us what Voodoo does.
Yeah, sure.

Voodoo is a company
that makes mobile games.

We're currently the world's leading
mobile game publisher.
And we're the second company

that gets the most downloads
on the AppStore, after Google .

All right.
And what are your challenges?
Our main challenges will be
to monetize our users and acquire them
so that, on our Ultra Casual games,

a user costs us 
less than he brings in, of course.

And in the end, to make our users
profitable and monetize them.
All right.

Today, you decided to share with us
this architecture.
Can you tell us about this app?

- What does it do?
- Yes, I can.
Well, this architecture

is the optimization
of our cross promotion.

So, it's the distribution
of Voodoo apps,
within Voodoo games.
It allows us to keep a user
as we release new games,
at a lower cost.
And, we try to maximize

the chances
that they will install our apps.
All right.
Can you tell us more about your use
of these services?
Yeah, sure.
So, when the user arrives,
our app will ask
for an advertisement
from all the Add Network we work with,
including ourselves.
Thanks to the user, it addresses a request
to us in our fairly classic ECS stack
with an ALB and an Auto Scaling Group
with EC2s on it.
This app will then call DynamoDB,

after performing
several business filters,
in order to get
all the necessary information
with all the features needed

to be able to invoke
our Machine Learning model.
And then, it will be able
to call our SageMaker EndPoint
in order to obtain all the predictions
for this user.

Each prediction represents
the probability
that this user will install

some of our apps by displaying
such advertisement.

And according to the best
probability of install,
we will be able to display this ad
to the user.
All right.
I see several, two S3 Buckets here,
can you tell us about this data?
Yeah, sure.

Well, this is actually
the preparation of the information
for our Machine Learning

Here in this Bucket,
we have our Data Lake.
And we're going to run a batch
of EMRs that will take
the information from our Data Lake,
aggregate, join,
merge multiple data sources,
and then create a dataset
and write it into another S3 Bucket.

- All right.
- This S3 Bucket, here,
is going to be used by Data Scientists
using Jupyter Notebooks.
So, right into SageMaker.
In order to be able
to test their models

and observe the offline
predictions of the model.
All right.

Once these predictions are
good enough for us,
we will be able to train a model
and deploy a new EndPoint.

And after that, that EndPoint
will take some of the traffic.
As a result, we can choose

how much of the traffic we want
to allocate to it.

At the beginning, we try to allocate
not too much traffic,

in order to validate only
the online performance.

And once the online performance
is validated,
we gradually increase the traffic
that this EndPoint will take.
All right.
And in terms of load on this app,

do you have some figures
to give us,

for example on the number
of calls to this model?
At the moment, I admit

that it's growing steadily,
but for the moment

we're going to have about 100 million
model invocations per day.

And each model invocation
will cause

about ten or even
fifteen predictions.

So that's several billion
predictions per day.

Because for one call
to our EndPoint,
we have to make one prediction
for each advertising campaign.

All right.
So, one of the advantages
is scalability in this case?
Yes.

Is there another advantage 
to using SageMaker for you?
For us, the main advantage

of SageMaker,
in addition to its scalability,
is really to make Data Scientists
completely autonomous.
That means that with our company,
in order to train a model,

retrieve online data
from our Data Lake,

and deploy a model,
a Data Scientist is fully autonomous.
We don't need a Data Engineer,
we don't need DevOps.
And DevOps can focus on industrializing
our infrastructures and architectures.
Our Data Engineers can focus

on really optimizing
our Dataset creation.
All right.

Thank you very much
for sharing this architecture with us,
it was very interesting.
Thank you very much.
And thank you and see you soon

for another episode
of This is My Architecture.

[Thank you for watching]
[For more information visit] 
[aws.amazon.com/this-is-my-architecture]
